Citation: Ferguson, C. J. (2013). Spanking, corporal punishment and negative long-term outcomes: A meta-analytic review of longitudinal studies. Clinical Psychology Review, 33(1), 196-208.
Where_to_Add: After current Gershoff (2002) and Straus & Paschall (2009) citations - adds meta-analytic evidence on effect sizes
Key_Gist: Meta-analysis of longitudinal studies: effect sizes are small (pr=.07-.10) when properly controlled, much smaller than bivariate estimates suggested

Citation: Heilmann, A., et al. (2021). Physical punishment and child outcomes: A narrative review. The Lancet, 398(10297), 355-364.
Where_to_Add: Strengthen longitudinal claims about punishment outcomes with recent large-scale narrative review
Key_Gist: Comprehensive narrative review of 69 longitudinal studies over 2-12 years: physical punishment consistently predicts behavior problems, never positive outcomes

Citation: Pan, Q., Chen, S., & Qu, Y. (2024). Corporal punishment and violent behavior spectrum: A meta-analytic review. Frontiers in Psychology, 15, 1323784.
Where_to_Add: Add to severity gradient discussion - demonstrates harsh vs mild punishment differential effects
Key_Gist: Severity matters: harsh corporal punishment shows stronger association with violence spectrum than mild punishment (dose-response relationship)

Citation: Taylor, C. A., et al. (2010). Mothers' spanking of 3-year-old children and subsequent risk of children's aggressive behavior. Pediatrics, 125(5), e1057-e1065.
Where_to_Add: Support behavioral cascade claims about punishment generalizing beyond target behavior
Key_Gist: Longitudinal evidence that spanking at age 3 predicts aggressive behavior - supports cascade beyond intended target

Citation: Talwar, V., & Lee, K. (2011). A punitive environment fosters children's dishonesty: A natural experiment. Child Development, 82(6), 1751-1758.
Where_to_Add: Strengthen adversarial example generation section - empirical support for deception learning
Key_Gist: Natural experiment: punitive environments increase child dishonesty - empirical evidence for adversarial example generation

Citation: MacKenzie, M. J., et al. (2015). Spanking and children's externalizing behavior across the first decade of life. Journal of Youth and Adolescence, 44(3), 658-669.
Where_to_Add: Add after current externalizing behavior claims - longitudinal evidence of spillover effects
Key_Gist: Decade-long longitudinal study: spanking effects persist and accumulate across childhood development

Citation: Bohn, J., et al. (2023). Consistency and specificity of attachments to parents, friends, and romantic partners in emerging adults. Emerging Adulthood, 11(2), 214-231.
Where_to_Add: After Ainsworth et al. (1978) - modern evidence on attachment consistency across relationships
Key_Gist: Large-scale study (N=512) using advanced SEM: attachments show moderate consistency (r=.3-.4) but most variance is relationship-specific, not general working model

Citation: Bosmans, G., & Kerns, K. A. (2020). A learning theory of attachment: Unraveling the black box of attachment development. Neuroscience & Biobehavioral Reviews, 113, 287-298.
Where_to_Add: Replace or supplement Bowlby/Ainsworth with contemporary learning-theory reformulation
Key_Gist: Proposes attachment as learning process with Hebbian mechanisms, bridging computational and attachment frameworks

Citation: Cassidy, J., & Shaver, P. R. (2013). Contributions of attachment theory and research. In Handbook of attachment (3rd ed., pp. 3-28). Guilford Press.
Where_to_Add: Add to attachment theory integration section (7.6) - comprehensive empirical validation
Key_Gist: Comprehensive empirical review: validates attachment consequences but with modest effect sizes and contextual dependence

Citation: Marquez, J., Francis-Hew, L., & Humphrey, N. (2023). Protective factors for resilience in adolescence: Analysis of a longitudinal dataset using the residuals approach. Child and Adolescent Psychiatry and Mental Health, 17, 124.
Where_to_Add: Section 3.6 and 5.3 - quantifies protective factor effects with large longitudinal sample
Key_Gist: Large UK longitudinal study (N=12,130): internal factors (self-esteem, emotion regulation) show strongest protective effects; external factors (friendships) also significant

Citation: Masten, A. S. (2001). Ordinary magic: Resilience processes in development. American Psychologist, 56(3), 227-238.
Where_to_Add: After current Masten citation - updates "ordinary magic" framework with recent evidence
Key_Gist: Foundational "ordinary magic" framework: resilience comes from ordinary processes (supportive relationships, self-regulation) not extraordinary traits

Citation: Vanderbilt-Adriance, E., & Shaw, D. S. (2008). Protective factors and the development of resilience in the context of neighborhood disadvantage. Journal of Abnormal Child Psychology, 36(6), 887-901.
Where_to_Add: Section 5.3 on generational trauma - demonstrates family vs external protective factors
Key_Gist: Longitudinal analysis: protective factors differ by risk level - family factors help at low risk, external factors critical at high risk

Citation: Miller-Lewis, L. R., et al. (2013). Resource factors for mental health resilience in early childhood. Child and Adolescent Mental Health, 18(1), 44-52.
Where_to_Add: Expand Section 3.4 absent positive experiences with empirical protective factor evidence
Key_Gist: Early childhood protective factors predict adolescent outcomes - supports prevention over intervention

Citation: Martin, J. S., et al. (2020). Harsh environments promote alloparental care across human societies. Proceedings of the Royal Society B, 287(1933), 20200758.
Where_to_Add: Section 5.4 - ecological validity across 141 societies showing environmental effects
Key_Gist: Cross-cultural analysis of 141 societies: alloparenting increases in harsh climates with low temperature/precipitation and unpredictable conditions

Citation: Emmott, E. H., & Mace, R. (2019). Alloparenting. In Encyclopedia of Evolutionary Psychological Science. Springer.
Where_to_Add: Add to anthropological evidence section - comprehensive cross-cultural framework
Key_Gist: Comprehensive review: alloparenting central to human evolution, varies by ecological pressures, involves kin and non-kin

Citation: Quinlan, R. J., & Quinlan, M. B. (2008). Human lactation, pair-bonds, and alloparents: A cross-cultural analysis. Human Nature, 19(1), 87-102.
Where_to_Add: Support nuclear family critique with empirical pair-bond and alloparenting trade-offs
Key_Gist: Data from 58 societies: pair-bond stability inversely related to breastfeeding duration, mediated by alloparent availability

Citation: Norman, J. (2020). Alloparenting: A historical perspective on infant "loving" care across cultures. Norland College Repository.
Where_to_Add: Historical context for alloparenting claims - extends beyond Hrdy (2009)
Key_Gist: Historical analysis: alloparenting normative across cultures until recent Western nuclear family isolation

Citation: Doucleff, M. (2023). Bringing up a baby can be a tough and lonely job: Alloparents across cultures. NPR Goats and Soda.
Where_to_Add: Practical implementation section - real-world examples of diverse caregiving
Key_Gist: NPR feature on modern research: infants average 8 alloparents, who provide 36% of care, reducing maternal burden

Citation: Chen, Z., et al. (2024). NRAT: Towards adversarial training with inherent label noise. Machine Learning, 113(6), 3589-3610.
Where_to_Add: Section 4 extreme penalties - direct ML evidence that noisy labels degrade adversarial training
Key_Gist: Noisy-Robust Adversarial Training (NRAT): label noise degrades AT performance; proposed method achieves state-of-art on trade-offs

Citation: Dong, C., Liu, L., & Shang, J. (2022). Label noise in adversarial training: A novel perspective to study robust overfitting. ICLR 2022.
Where_to_Add: Support weight cascade mechanism with formal adversarial training analysis
Key_Gist: Label noise in AT causes robust overfitting - mismatch between adversarial and clean label distributions drives performance degradation

Citation: Tu, Y., et al. (2023). Learning with noisy labels via self-supervised adversarial noisy masking. CVPR 2023, 6139-6146.
Where_to_Add: Add to overfitting discussion - shows how label noise prevents generalization
Key_Gist: Adversarial noisy masking: models trained on clean vs mislabeled samples show distinguishable activation patterns - supports Pattern distinction

Citation: Yu, D., et al. (2024). Soften to defend: Towards adversarial robustness via self-guided label refinement. CVPR 2024.
Where_to_Add: Strengthen computational validation - self-guided refinement mirrors therapy retraining
Key_Gist: Self-guided label refinement reduces robust overfitting by softening hard labels - mirrors therapeutic gradual exposure

Citation: Zhou, D., et al. (2022). Modeling adversarial noise for adversarial training. ICML 2022.
Where_to_Add: Add to gradient magnitude analysis - demonstrates label distribution mismatch effects
Key_Gist: Models adversarial noise as transition matrix in label space - explicit computational framework for perturbation effects

Citation: Kirkpatrick, J., et al. (2017). Overcoming catastrophic forgetting in neural networks. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 114(13), 3521-3526.
Where_to_Add: Section 5.6 prevention vs treatment - foundational paper on forgetting mechanisms
Key_Gist: Foundational paper (10,988 citations): elastic weight consolidation (EWC) protects important weights - demonstrates forgetting is solvable but difficult

Citation: van de Ven, G. M., Tuytelaars, T., & Tolias, A. S. (2024). Continual learning and catastrophic forgetting. arXiv:2403.05175.
Where_to_Add: Add comprehensive review of continual learning - updates theoretical foundations
Key_Gist: Comprehensive 2024 review: surveys gradient-based, regularization, and replay approaches to mitigate forgetting

Citation: Li, B., Wang, Y., & Liu, W. (2025). Towards understanding catastrophic forgetting in two-layer convolutional neural networks. ICML 2025.
Where_to_Add: Support retraining difficulty claims with formal analysis of CNN forgetting
Key_Gist: Theoretical analysis: CNNs forget features with weaker signals even if stable - explains why retraining harder than initial training

Citation: Ans, B., et al. (2004). A self-refreshing memory architecture for lifelong learning. Connection Science, 16(2), 71-99.
Where_to_Add: Historical context - early dual-network approaches to memory preservation
Key_Gist: Historical dual-network approach: separate networks for different tasks with pseudo-item self-refresh

Citation: Khalfa, S., & Touzet, C. F. (2017). EMDR therapy mechanisms explained by the theory of neural cognition. Journal of Trauma & Stress Disorders & Treatment, 6(4).
Where_to_Add: Section 7.2 clinical applications - neural mechanism explanation via LTP/LTD
Key_Gist: Theory of Neural Cognition account: EMDR bilateral stimulation modifies traumatic memory traces via LTP/LTD, incorporating new cortical columns

Citation: Landin-Romero, R., et al. (2018). How does eye movement desensitization and reprocessing therapy work? A systematic review. Frontiers in Psychology, 9, 1395.
Where_to_Add: Comprehensive review of EMDR mechanisms - supports memory reconsolidation claims
Key_Gist: Systematic review of 87 studies: reasonable support for working memory hypothesis and physiological changes; neuroimaging shows neural correlates

Citation: de Jongh, A., et al. (2024). State of the science: Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing therapy. Journal of Traumatic Stress, 37(1), 8-28.
Where_to_Add: Add recent meta-analysis evidence for EMDR efficacy and mechanisms
Key_Gist: Recent meta-analysis and state-of-science: EMDR effective, differs from exposure via reconsolidation mechanisms

Citation: Chamberlin, D. E. (2019). The predictive processing model of EMDR. Frontiers in Psychology, 10, 2267.
Where_to_Add: Predictive processing framework for EMDR - integrates with computational approach
Key_Gist: Predictive processing framework: EMDR overcomes bias against evidence accumulation, eye movements reset theta rhythm and facilitate mnemonic search

Citation: Craske, M. G., et al. (2014). Maximizing exposure therapy: An inhibitory learning approach. Behaviour Research and Therapy, 58, 10-23.
Where_to_Add: Section 7.2 - foundational inhibitory learning theory replacing habituation model
Key_Gist: Inhibitory learning model: exposure forms new inhibitory associations rather than erasing fear memories - paradigm shift from habituation

Citation: Raeder, F., et al. (2020). The association between fear extinction, the ability to accomplish exposure, and exposure therapy outcome. Scientific Reports, 10, 3667.
Where_to_Add: Empirical validation of extinction-exposure link in clinical populations
Key_Gist: Fear extinction predicts ability to complete exposure and therapy outcomes - validates extinction as mechanism

Citation: Jacoby, R. J., & Abramowitz, J. S. (2016). Inhibitory learning approaches to exposure therapy. Current Opinion in Psychology, 2, 28-33.
Where_to_Add: Clinical implementation guidelines for inhibitory learning approach
Key_Gist: Clinical implementation: strategies include expectancy violation, varied contexts, removing safety behaviors

Citation: Benito, K. G., & Walther, M. (2015). Therapeutic process during exposure: Habituation model. Clinical Psychology Review, 41, 61-71.
Where_to_Add: Historical context on habituation vs inhibitory learning models
Key_Gist: Habituation neither necessary nor sufficient for exposure success - learning mechanisms more important than fear reduction

Citation: van de Schoot, R., et al. (2019). The effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy: A review, meta-analysis, and meta-regression analysis. European Journal of Psychotraumatology, 10(1), 1566303.
Where_to_Add: Section 7.2 therapeutic implications - meta-analysis showing large effect sizes (g=1.18-1.37)
Key_Gist: Meta-analysis: NET effective for PTSD with large effect sizes at post-treatment (g=1.18) and follow-up (g=1.37), better for older adults

Citation: Schirmer, M., et al. (2024). The language of trauma: Modeling traumatic event descriptions. EMNLP 2024 Findings, 773.
Where_to_Add: Computational modeling of trauma narratives - supports reprocessing mechanisms
Key_Gist: Transformer models (RoBERTa) predict traumatic event descriptions with 71-74% F1 score - computational validation of trauma narratives

Citation: Kriegeskorte, N., & Douglas, P. K. (2018). Cognitive computational neuroscience. Nature Neuroscience, 21(9), 1148-1160.
Where_to_Add: Section 2.3 - bridges cognitive science, neuroscience, AI with task-performing models
Key_Gist: Foundational framework: combines cognitive task performance, neurobiological plausibility, and AI methods - defines the field

Citation: Philippsen, A., Yoshikawa, Y., & Nagai, T. (2022). Simulating developmental and individual differences of drawing with predictive coding. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 828631.
Where_to_Add: Support predictive coding framework in development - empirical Bayesian inference in children
Key_Gist: Recurrent neural network with Bayesian inference: simulates drawing development via precision-weighted integration of priors and sensory data

Citation: Gopnik, A., & Wellman, H. M. (2015). Bayesian models of child development. Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Cognitive Science, 6(2), 75-86.
Where_to_Add: Foundational Bayesian models of child learning - theoretical grounding
Key_Gist: Bayesian child learning: children as rational statistical learners performing inference over experience

Citation: Rapaport, H., et al. (2023). Investigating predictive coding in younger and older children. Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience, 60, 101205.
Where_to_Add: Demonstrates predictive coding maturation across child development
Key_Gist: MMF amplitude increases with age, reflecting more precise priors and stronger prediction errors - empirical developmental evidence

Citation: Rmus, M., et al. (2024). Artificial neural networks for model identification and parameter estimation in computational cognitive models. PLOS Computational Biology, 20(5), e1012119.
Where_to_Add: Validation of using ANNs for cognitive modeling - methodological support
Key_Gist: ANNs can fit cognitive models bypassing likelihood estimation - validates simulation-based approaches

Citation: Lewkowycz, A., et al. (2020). On the training dynamics of deep networks with L2 regularization. NeurIPS 2020.
Where_to_Add: Section 5.2 and throughout ML discussions - training dynamics and regularization theory
Key_Gist: L2 regularization shrinks weights toward zero, affects training dynamics and generalization differently across network depth

Citation: Wang, Y., et al. (2019). Convolutional neural networks with dynamic regularization. IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, 32(6), 2299-2312.
Where_to_Add: Dynamic regularization matching training phases - supports prevention arguments
Key_Gist: Dynamic regularization adapts strength during training: increase when training loss drops (prevent overfitting), decrease when stagnant

Citation: Northcutt, C. G., Jiang, L., & Chuang, I. L. (2021). Confident learning: Estimating uncertainty in dataset labels. Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research, 70, 1373-1411.
Where_to_Add: Add to training data quality discussion - confident learning under label uncertainty
Key_Gist: Confident learning: identifies and corrects label errors in training data, improving generalization under uncertainty
